description:
The Torque teno mini virus 8 (TTMV8) is a small, single-stranded DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. It is a member of the Betatorquevirus genus, which encompasses a diverse group of viruses found in various vertebrate hosts, including humans.

The TTMV8 virion is approximately 30-32 nanometers in diameter and has a circular, closed-circular DNA genome of around 2.8-3.2 kilobases in length. The viral genome encodes a limited number of proteins, typically associated with viral replication, transcription, and structural components.

TTMV8 is primarily known as a human commensal virus, meaning it is frequently detected in the human population, often without causing any apparent clinical symptoms or disease. The virus is believed to be widely distributed globally, with prevalence rates varying across different geographical regions and populations.

While the exact role and significance of TTMV8 in human health and disease remain subjects of ongoing research, some studies have suggested potential associations between the presence of TTMV8 and certain medical conditions, such as liver diseases and immunological disorders. However, the causal relationships, if any, are not yet fully understood.

Continued scientific investigation into the epidemiology, molecular biology, and potential clinical implications of TTMV8 will help expand our understanding of this intriguing member of the Anelloviridae family and its interactions with the human host.
